title: X Corp.
content:
{{Use American English|date=August 2023}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2023}}
{{Short description|American technology company}}
{{redirect|X Corporation|the fictional Marvel Comics institution|X-Corporation}}
{{Other uses|X Corps (disambiguation)|X (disambiguation)#Companies}}
{{Infobox company
| name = X Corp.
| logo = X logo 2023.svg
| logo_size = 100px

* [[Technology]]

* [[Internet]]}}
| predecessor = [[Twitter, Inc.]]
| founded = {{Start date and age|2023|03|09|mf=yes}}{{efn|In an April 4, 2023, court filing,  [[Twitter, Inc.]] disclosed that it no longer existed and was consolidated into X Corp. The corporation was created under [[Nevada corporation|Nevada corporate law]] on March 9, 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/twitter-nevada-musk-1f998f30 |title=Twitter Inc. 'No Longer Exists.' Why Elon Musk Chose Nevada For X Holdings. |date=April 11, 2023 |last=Smith |first=Connor |work=[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230412031849/https://www.barrons.com/articles/twitter-nevada-musk-1f998f30 |url-status=live }}</ref>}}
| founder = [[Elon Musk]]
| hq_location_city = [[San Francisco, California]]
| hq_location_country = US
| area_served = Worldwide
| key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[Elon Musk]] ([[Chairman]] & [[Chief technology officer|CTO]])|[[Linda Yaccarino]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])}}
| services = [[X (social network)|X]] (formerly Twitter)
| owner = Elon Musk (74%)<ref>{{cite web|access-date=5 September 2023|language=en|title=Elon Musk|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/elon-musk/|website=Forbes|archive-date=February 10, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210112624/http://www.forbes.com/profile/elon-musk/|url-status=live}}<!-- auto-translated by Module:CS1 translator --></ref>
| parent = X Holdings Corp.
| num_employees = {{circa|1,500}} (August 2023)<ref>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/article/twitter-x-corp-ceo-linda-yaccarino-elon-musk-0131c61ac296955d424fd057f6b0196d |title=Twitter-turned-X CEO Linda Yaccarino focuses on winning back big brands on Elon Musk's platform |date=August 10, 2023 |publisher=Associated Press |access-date=August 13, 2023 |archive-date=October 8, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231008165105/https://apnews.com/article/twitter-x-corp-ceo-linda-yaccarino-elon-musk-0131c61ac296955d424fd057f6b0196d |url-status=live }}</ref>
| website = {{Official URL}}
}}
{{Elon Musk series}}
'''X Corp.''' is an American [[technology company]] established by [[Elon Musk]] in 2023 as the successor to [[Twitter, Inc.]] It is a wholly owned subsidiary of X Holdings Corp., which is itself owned by Musk. The company owns the social networking service X (formerly [[Twitter]]) and has announced plans to use it as a base for other offerings.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Ryan|title=Twitter partners with eToro to let users trade stocks, crypto as Musk pushes app into finance|date=April 13, 2023|agency=CNBC|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/04/13/twitter-to-let-users-access-stocks-crypto-via-etoro-in-finance-push.html|access-date=April 13, 2023|archive-date=April 13, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230413082513/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/04/13/twitter-to-let-users-access-stocks-crypto-via-etoro-in-finance-push.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Capoot |first=Ashley |date=July 29, 2023 |title=X logo officially replaces Twitter's famous bird on mobile app, building headquarters |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/29/x-logo-officially-replaces-twitters-famous-bird-on-mobile-app-.html |access-date=August 1, 2023 |website=CNBC |language=en |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731224836/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/07/29/x-logo-officially-replaces-twitters-famous-bird-on-mobile-app-.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

==History==
===Conceptualization and planning (2022–2023)===
{{Further|Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk|Twitter under Elon Musk}}
In April 2022, filings to the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) revealed Musk had formed three corporate entities in [[Delaware]], all under the name of X Holdings. According to the filings, one of the entities was to merge with [[Twitter, Inc.]], while another was to serve as the parent company of the newly merged company. A third entity would then help take on a {{USD|13}} billion loan provided by various large banks to acquire [[Twitter]].<ref name="SlateInfo">{{Cite web |url=https://slate.com/technology/2023/04/twitter-inc-x-corp-elon-musk-x-nevada.html |title=Twitter Isn't a Company Anymore |date=April 10, 2023 |last1=Pahwa |first1=Nitish |last2=Joseph Stern |first2=Mark |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230418023557/https://slate.com/technology/2023/04/twitter-inc-x-corp-elon-musk-x-nevada.html |url-status=live }}</ref> 

The name "X" dates back to [[X.com (bank)|X.com]], an online bank co-founded by Musk in 1999. In March 2000, X.com merged with competitor [[Confinity]] to create [[PayPal]].{{Sfn|Vance|2017|p=77-78}} Musk considered forming a holding company named "X" for [[Tesla, Inc.]] and [[SpaceX]] in August 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-spacex/musk-says-may-form-holding-company-for-tesla-spacex-idUSBRE87U0KR20120831 |title=Musk says may form holding company for Tesla, SpaceX |date=August 31, 2012 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230412033240/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-spacex/musk-says-may-form-holding-company-for-tesla-spacex-idUSBRE87U0KR20120831 |url-status=live }}</ref> In July 2017, Musk reacquired the domain X.com, for an undisclosed amount, from PayPal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://qz.com/1026167/elon-musk-just-bought-x-com-the-domain-he-once-owned-from-paypal |title=Elon Musk bought a web domain worth millions with "sentimental value" to him |date=July 11, 2017 |last=Huang |first=Echo |work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230412033241/https://qz.com/1026167/elon-musk-just-bought-x-com-the-domain-he-once-owned-from-paypal |url-status=live }}</ref> Musk reaffirmed his support for the name "X" in December 2020, replying to a Twitter user who renewed calls for Musk to form a new holding company under that name, although he dismissed the idea of X acquiring his businesses.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-04-21/musk-forms-x-holdings-after-hints-at-parent-for-tesla-spacex |title=Musk Forms 'X Holdings' After Hints at a Parent Company for Tesla, SpaceX |date=April 21, 2022 |last=O'Kane |first=Sean |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230416071316/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-04-21/musk-forms-x-holdings-after-hints-at-parent-for-tesla-spacex |url-status=live }}</ref>

The concept for X solidified in October 2022, when Musk tweeted that acquiring Twitter is "an accelerant to creating X, the [[Super-app|everything app]]". According to Musk, Twitter would accelerate the creation of X by "3 to 5 years". Musk expressed interest in creating an app similar to [[WeChat]]—a Chinese instant messaging, social media, and mobile payment app—on a podcast in May 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/06/technology/elon-musk-x.html |title=What Does X Mean to Elon Musk? |date=October 6, 2022 |last=Huang |first=Kalley |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230410133325/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/06/technology/elon-musk-x.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In June, Musk told Twitter employees that Twitter is a "digital town square" that should be all-encompassing, like WeChat.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/16/technology/elon-musk-twitter-employees-meeting.html |title=Elon Musk tells Twitter's employees he wants the service to 'contribute to a better, long-lasting civilization.' |date=June 16, 2022 |last=Isaac |first=Mike |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=January 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230114225902/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/16/technology/elon-musk-twitter-employees-meeting.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In a [[Morgan Stanley]] conference in March 2023, Musk touted X once again as the potentially "biggest financial institution in the world".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/dereksaul/2023/03/07/musks-new-twitter-dream-become-biggest-financial-institution-in-the-world/ |title=Musk's New Twitter Dream: Become 'Biggest Financial Institution In The World' |date=March 7, 2023 |last=Saul |first=Derek |work=[[Forbes]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230412040417/https://www.forbes.com/sites/dereksaul/2023/03/07/musks-new-twitter-dream-become-biggest-financial-institution-in-the-world/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On October 27, 2022, Musk [[Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk|acquired]] Twitter for $44 billion, and subsequently became its [[Chief executive officer|CEO]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/27/technology/elon-musk-twitter-deal-complete.html |title=Elon Musk Completes $44 Billion Deal to Own Twitter |date=October 27, 2022 |last1=Conger |first1=Kate |last2=Hirsch |first2=Lauren |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=October 29, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221029090805/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/27/technology/elon-musk-twitter-deal-complete.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

===Formation (2023–present)===
In March 2023, Musk registered X Corp. in [[Nevada]]. On the same day, Musk registered the [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) company [[xAI (company)|X.AI]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/4/14/23684005/elon-musk-new-ai-company-x |title=Elon Musk founds new AI company called X.AI |date=April 14, 2023 |last1=Peters |first1=Jay |last2=Roth |first2=Emma |publisher=[[The Verge]] |access-date=April 14, 2023 |archive-date=April 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230414223834/https://www.theverge.com/2023/4/14/23684005/elon-musk-new-ai-company-x |url-status=live }}</ref> Later that month, Musk applied to merge X Holdings I with X Holdings Corp. and [[Twitter, Inc.]] with X Corp.<ref name="SlateInfo"/> In the filing, Musk revealed that X Holdings Corp. had $2 million in capital, but X Holdings Corp. would serve as the parent company for X Corp.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/technology/2023/04/11/ex-twitter-chief-executive-parag-agrawal-reveals-doj-probe-in-pursuit-of-legal-fees-repayment/ |title=Twitter becomes X Corporation as Musk advances 'everything app' hopes |last=Feeley |first=Jef |newspaper=[[The Irish Times]] |access-date=April 11, 2023}}</ref> In a company-wide email that month, Musk announced that Twitter employees would receive stock in X Corp.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/elon-musk-twitter-value.html |title=Elon Musk Values Twitter at $20 Billion |date=March 26, 2023 |last1=Conger |first1=Kate |last2=Mac |first2=Ryan |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230411034427/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/elon-musk-twitter-value.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

In an April 2023 court filing for an ongoing lawsuit filed by political activist [[Laura Loomer]] against Twitter and its former CEO [[Jack Dorsey]], Twitter, Inc. notified the court that it had been consolidated into X Corp., a Nevada corporation based in [[Carson City, Nevada|Carson City]]. A similar filing was made in the [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://sfstandard.com/business/twitter-is-now-called-x-corp-and-no-longer-exists/ |title=Twitter Is Now Called X Corp and 'No Longer Exists' |date=April 11, 2023 |last=Gaus |first=Annie |work=[[The San Francisco Standard]] |access-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-date=April 11, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230411211347/https://sfstandard.com/business/twitter-is-now-called-x-corp-and-no-longer-exists/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

On May 11, 2023, Musk tweeted that he had found his replacement as Twitter and X Corp.'s CEO. The next day, on May 12, 2023, he named [[Linda Yaccarino]] as the new CEO, adding that she "will focus primarily on business operations, while I focus on product design & new technology".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/5/12/23721107/twitter-ceo-linda-yaccarino-elon-musk-nbc |title=Twitter's new CEO is Linda Yaccarino, a longtime ad exec for NBCU |date=May 12, 2023 |last=Roth |first=Emma |work=[[The Verge]] |access-date=May 12, 2023 |archive-date=May 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230512160254/https://www.theverge.com/2023/5/12/23721107/twitter-ceo-linda-yaccarino-elon-musk-nbc |url-status=live }}</ref> Musk said he would transition his role to executive chairman and chief technology officer.<ref name="VarietyCEO">{{cite web |last=Spangler |first=Todd |date=May 12, 2023 |title=Elon Musk Confirms Linda Yaccarino as Twitter's New CEO, Focused on Business Operations |url=https://variety.com/2023/digital/news/linda-yaccarino-twitter-ceo-musk-confirms-1235611144/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |access-date=June 6, 2023 |archive-date=July 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230728161719/https://variety.com/2023/digital/news/linda-yaccarino-twitter-ceo-musk-confirms-1235611144/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Yaccarino succeeded Musk on June 5, 2023.<ref name=twtr-ceo>{{cite news |last=Frier |first=Sarah |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Twitter's New CEO Linda Yaccarino Has First Day in the Role |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-06/twitter-s-new-ceo-yaccarino-has-first-day-in-the-role |publisher=Bloomberg News |access-date=June 6, 2023 |archive-date=June 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230626134649/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-06/twitter-s-new-ceo-yaccarino-has-first-day-in-the-role |url-status=live }}</ref>

At the end of May 2023, [[Fidelity Investments]] estimated the company's value at $15 billion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Twitter's U.S. Ad Sales Plunge 59% as Woes Continue |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/05/technology/twitter-ad-sales-musk.html |work=The New York TImes |date=June 5, 2023 |author1=Ryan Mac |author2=Tiffany Hsu |access-date=June 5, 2023 |archive-date=October 19, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231019232412/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/05/technology/twitter-ad-sales-musk.html |url-status=live }}</ref> This was later increased to a value of $27 billion by July,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://benzinga.com/markets/mutual-funds/23/08/33501596/fidelity-increases-valuation-on-x-after-twitter-name-change-heres-how-much-the-social-media- |first=Chris |last=Katje |website=[[Benzinga]] |date=August 1, 2023 |title=Fidelity Increases Valuation On X After Twitter Name Change: Here's How Much The Social Media Platform Is Worth |access-date=August 31, 2023 |archive-date=October 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231014181334/https://www.benzinga.com/markets/mutual-funds/23/08/33501596/fidelity-increases-valuation-on-x-after-twitter-name-change-heres-how-much-the-social-media- |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.axios.com/2023/07/31/fidelity-marks-up-its-twitterx-shares-for-second-straight-month |website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |first=Dan |last=Primack |date=July 31, 2023 |title=Fidelity marks up its Twitter/X shares for second straight month |access-date=August 31, 2023 |archive-date=September 1, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230901031813/https://www.axios.com/2023/07/31/fidelity-marks-up-its-twitterx-shares-for-second-straight-month |url-status=live }}</ref> and up to about $28.5 billion by the end of August.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://teslarati.com/elon-musk-x-1-trillion-market-cap-not-out-of-the-question |website=Teslarati |first=Simon |last=Alvarez |date=August 23, 2023 |title=Elon Musk shares optimistic outlook for X: $1T market cap “not out of the question” |access-date=August 31, 2023 |archive-date=September 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230903174756/https://www.teslarati.com/elon-musk-x-1-trillion-market-cap-not-out-of-the-question/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://axios.com/2023/08/30/elon-musks-x-value-fidelity |first=Dan |last=Primack |website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |date=August 30, 2023 |title=Elon Musk's X is gaining value, Fidelity says |access-date=August 31, 2023 |archive-date=September 22, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230922164935/https://www.axios.com/2023/08/30/elon-musks-x-value-fidelity |url-status=live }}</ref>

The company erected a giant illuminated "X" on the roof of its San Francisco headquarters in July 2023 without obtaining required permits. 24 complaints were filed by neighbors concerned about the bright flashing light and structural integrity. Inspectors were twice denied roof access, and the city cited the company for a building code violation. X removed the sign after a few days.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/30/tech/san-francisco-investigates-twitter-x-sign/index.html |website=[[CNN]] |first=Jamiel |last=Lynch |date=July 31, 2023 |title=A flashing 'X' was installed atop the San Francisco headquarters following Twitter's rebrand. A city complaint says the sign went up without a permit |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=August 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230810034845/https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/30/tech/san-francisco-investigates-twitter-x-sign/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/brightly-flashing-sign-removed-former-twitters-san-francisco-101884217 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |work=[[The Associated Press]] |date=July 31, 2023 |title=Brightly flashing 'X' sign removed from the San Francisco building that was Twitter's headquarters |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909122615/https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/brightly-flashing-sign-removed-former-twitters-san-francisco-101884217 |url-status=live }}</ref>

In August 2023, CEO Linda Yaccarino stated that she has "operational autonomy" under owner Elon Musk to run the business, and that she is involved in everything that goes into running the company.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cnbc.com/2023/08/10/x-corp-ceo-linda-yaccarino-says-she-has-autonomy-under-elon-musk.html |first=Rohan |last=Goswami |website=[[CNBC]] |title=X CEO Linda Yaccarino explains reason for getting rid of Twitter name |date=August 10, 2023 |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=October 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231014122421/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/10/x-corp-ceo-linda-yaccarino-says-she-has-autonomy-under-elon-musk.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://nbcnews.com/business/business-news/twitter-x-ceo-linda-yaccarino-automony-from-elon-musk-run-business-rcna99202 |first=Rob |last=Wile |website=[[NBC News]] |date=August 10, 2023 |title=Linda Yaccarino, CEO of X, says she has autonomy from Elon Musk to run the business |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=October 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018085032/https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/twitter-x-ceo-linda-yaccarino-automony-from-elon-musk-run-business-rcna99202 |url-status=live }}</ref> Yaccarino also opened up on the reasoning behind Twitter's "controversial" name change to X,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nytimes.com/2023/08/03/technology/twitter-x-tweets-elon-musk.html |first=Kate |last=Conger |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 3, 2023 |title=So What Do We Call Twitter Now Anyway? |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=October 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231012220459/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/03/technology/twitter-x-tweets-elon-musk.html |url-status=live }}</ref> wherein she stated that the rebranding was essentially a "liberation" from Twitter. Yaccarino also went on to say that if users had stayed with Twitter, then changes would only be "incremental" and that with X, they think about "what's possible".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/linda-yaccarino-twitter-elon-musk-justify-x-rebrand-1850726989 |first=Kyle |last=Barr |website=[[Gizmodo]] |date=August 11, 2023 |title=Twitter's CEO Makes New Excuses for Musk's Dumb 'X' Rebranding |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=October 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018155649/https://gizmodo.com/linda-yaccarino-twitter-elon-musk-justify-x-rebrand-1850726989 |url-status=live }}</ref>

In October 2023, the marketing agency X Social Media filed a lawsuit against X Corp alleging a violation its trademark of the letter X.<ref>{{cite web |title=Elon Musk's X hit with trademark lawsuit from marketing agency |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/elon-musks-x-hit-with-trademark-lawsuit-marketing-agency-2023-10-02/ |publisher=Reuters |access-date=October 7, 2023 |archive-date=October 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231007192445/https://www.reuters.com/technology/elon-musks-x-hit-with-trademark-lawsuit-marketing-agency-2023-10-02/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Controversies ==
=== Center for Countering Digital Hate ===
On June 1, 2023, the [[Center for Countering Digital Hate]] (CCDH) reported that X, formerly named Twitter, had "failed to act" on 99% of hate posted by [[Twitter Blue]] subscribers. The CCDH then described several tweets containing such hateful messages that allegedly contained "[[racist]], [[homophobic]], [[neo-Nazi]], [[antisemitic]] or [[conspiracy]] content".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theguardian.com/technology/2023/jul/31/anti-hate-speech-group-accuses-elon-musk-x-corp-intimidation |first=Dan |last=Milmo |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 31, 2023 |title=Anti-hate speech group accuses Elon Musk's X Corp of intimidation over legal threat |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=October 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231016213008/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/jul/31/anti-hate-speech-group-accuses-elon-musk-x-corp-intimidation |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Field |first1=Hayden |title=Twitter, now called X, sues researchers who showed rise in hate speech on platform after Musk takeover |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/01/x-sues-ccdh-for-showing-hate-speech-rise-on-twitter-after-musk-deal.html |publisher=CNBC |access-date=September 9, 2023 |archive-date=September 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230906133857/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/01/x-sues-ccdh-for-showing-hate-speech-rise-on-twitter-after-musk-deal.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

In response, X Corp. mentioned that the platform encouraged [[Human genetic variation|diversity]] and [[Freedom of speech|free speech]], stating that "more than 99.99% of post impressions are healthy" in a blog post.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcmag.com/news/twitter-claims-99-of-its-content-is-healthy-internet-rolls-eyes |first=Michael |last=Kan |date=July 19, 2023 |title=Twitter Claims 99% of Its Content Is Healthy, Internet Rolls Eyes |website=[[PCMag]] |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=August 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230824000141/https://www.pcmag.com/news/twitter-claims-99-of-its-content-is-healthy-internet-rolls-eyes |url-status=live }}</ref> The post further mentioned that the CCDH was spreading "false and misleading claims" that might have negative financial repercussions as it encouraged advertisers to halt investment on X.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/31/technology/twitter-x-center-for-countering-digital-hate.html |author=Sheera Frenkel, Ryan Mac |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 31, 2023 |title=Twitter Sues Nonprofit That Tracks Hate Speech |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=October 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231016193843/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/31/technology/twitter-x-center-for-countering-digital-hate.html |url-status=live }}</ref> The blog also further described the CCDH as a "scare campaign" working continuously to prevent "public dialogue", alleging that the CCDH's research utilized metrics that were purposely put "out of context to make unsubstantiated assertions about X".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://time.com/6301841/6301841/ |first=Simmone |last=Shah |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 4, 2023 |title=Elon Musk's X Corp Is Suing an Anti-Hate-Speech Group. Here's What They Have to Say |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=October 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231020104158/https://time.com/6301841/6301841/ |url-status=live }}</ref> X then filed a [[legal claim]] against CCDH and the [[European Climate Foundation]], which it alleged was providing the information used in CCDH's research, and that X denied all claims stated by the CCDH.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://wired.com/story/twitter-x-ccdh-lawsuit-data-crackdown |first=Vittoria |last=Elliot |date=August 15, 2023 |magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |title=How X Is Suing Its Way Out of Accountability |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=October 11, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231011201615/https://www.wired.com/story/twitter-x-ccdh-lawsuit-data-crackdown/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cnbc.com/2023/08/01/x-sues-ccdh-for-showing-hate-speech-rise-on-twitter-after-musk-deal.html |first=Hayden |last=Field |website=[[CNBC]] |date=August 1, 2023 |title=Twitter, now called X, sues researchers who showed rise in hate speech on platform after Musk takeover |access-date=August 23, 2023 |archive-date=October 10, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010151436/https://www.cnbc.com/2023/08/01/x-sues-ccdh-for-showing-hate-speech-rise-on-twitter-after-musk-deal.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Antisemitism ===
On November 16, [[Media Matters for America]], a left-leaning watchdog group, published a report stating that X was placing ads for various companies including [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[IBM]], and [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]], alongside pro-Nazi content.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mediamatters.org/twitter/musk-endorses-antisemitic-conspiracy-theory-x-has-been-placing-ads-apple-bravo-ibm-oracle |first=Eric |last=Hananoki |date=November 16, 2023 |title=As Musk endorses antisemitic conspiracy theory, X has been placing ads for Apple, Bravo, IBM, Oracle, and Xfinity next to pro-Nazi content |publisher=[[Media Matters for America]] |access-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231127005158/https://www.mediamatters.org/twitter/musk-endorses-antisemitic-conspiracy-theory-x-has-been-placing-ads-apple-bravo-ibm-oracle |url-status=live }}</ref> Published following Musk's endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory, major advertisers like [[Microsoft Corporation|Microsoft]] and Apple fled the platform, leading to an estimated loss of around $75 million by the end of 2023.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/24/business/x-elon-musk-advertisers.html |author=Ryan Mac and Kate Conger |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 24, 2023 |title=X May Lose Up to $75 Million in Revenue as More Advertisers Pull Out |access-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231127000830/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/24/business/x-elon-musk-advertisers.html |url-status=live }}</ref> This led to a lawsuit by X Corp. against Media Matters, alleging that they had "exploited" the platform into making the ads appear the way they did as a result of excessive scrolling and curating its feed with "fringe" content.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.axios.com/2023/11/21/x-elon-musk-sues-media-matters-antisemitic-ads |first=Kerry |last=Flynn |website=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |date=November 20, 2023 |title=Elon Musk's X sues Media Matters for America |access-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231127052738/https://www.axios.com/2023/11/21/x-elon-musk-sues-media-matters-antisemitic-ads |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/elon-musk-media-matters-lawsuit-advertising-neonazi-1fe499daa600f513af27ffa68d2e8b91 |first=Barbara |last=Orturay |newspaper=[[The Associated Press]] |date=November 21, 2023 |title=Musk’s X sues liberal advocacy group Media Matters over its report on ads next to hate groups’ posts |access-date=November 27, 2023 |archive-date=November 21, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121094525/https://apnews.com/article/elon-musk-media-matters-lawsuit-advertising-neonazi-1fe499daa600f513af27ffa68d2e8b91 |url-status=live }}</ref>
